Introduction

This manual describes the programming language Cool: the CClassroom OObject-OOriented LLanguage. Cool is a small language that can be implemented with reasonable effort in a one semester course. Still, Cool retains many of the features of modern programming languages including objects, static typing, and automatic memory management.

Cool programs are sets of classesclasses. A class encapsulates the variables and procedures of a data type. Instances of a class are objectsobjects. In Cool, classes and types are identified. That is, every class defines a type. Classes permit programmers to define new types and associated procedures (or methodsmethods) specific to those types. Inheritance allows new types to extend the behavior of existing types.

Cool is an expressionexpression language. Most Cool constructs are expressions, and every expression has a value and a type. Cool is type safetype safe: procedures are guaranteed to be applied to data of the correct type. While static typing imposes a strong discipline on programming in Cool, it guarantees that no runtime type errors can arise in the execution of Cool programs.

This manual is divided into informal and formal components. For a short, informal overview, the first half (through Section 9) suffices. The formal description begins with Section 10.

Getting Started

Cool source files have extension .cl.cl. The programming projects will also define other file formats related to Cool but they are not officially part of the language specification.

You can obtain the Cool interpreter coolcool from the course website. To interpret (i.e., run) a Cool program: 

cool file.cl

This official version is often called the reference implementationreference implementation and you are encouraged to use it as a point of comparison when you are designing and testing parts of the course project. The reference Cool interpreter has been specifically structured so that you can run the various stages (i.e., lexing, parsing, type-checking and interpreting) independently. This power is useful for PA2 through PA5.

The Cool interpreter has an number of command-line options:

--lex
This option causes Cool to stop after lexing and produce a new file, file.cl–lexfile.cl–lex, which contains the lexed tokens in a simple interchange format. Handy for PA2.
--unlex
This option causes Cool to undo lexing and produce file.cl2file.cl2 (a Cool source file) from the lexed tokens. This is usually used as a debugging aid for PA2 by feeding Cool a file.cl–lexfile.cl–lex file produced by your lexeryour lexer from file.clfile.cl and then comparing file.cl2file.cl2 to the original filefile.cl.
--parse
This option causes Cool to stop after parsing and produce a new file, file.cl–astfile.cl–ast, which contains the abstract syntax tree in a simple interchange format. Handy for PA3.
--unparse
This option causes Cool to undo parsing and produce file.cl3file.cl3 (a Cool source file) from the abstract syntax tree. This is usually used as a debugging aid for PA3 by feeding Cool a file.cl–astfile.cl–ast file produced by your parser from file.clfile.cl and then comparing file.cl3file.cl3 to the original file.clfile.cl.
--type
This option causes Cool to stop after type checking and semantic analysis and produce a new file, file.cl–typefile.cl–type, which contains the class mapping and implementation mapping in a simple interchange format. Handy for PA4.
--class-map
This option causes Cool to stop after type checking and semantic analysis and produce a new file, file.cl–typefile.cl–type, which contains the class mapping only in a simple interchange format. Handy for the PA4 Checkpoint (WA4).
--imp-map
This option causes Cool to stop after type checking and semantic analysis and produce a new file, file.cl–typefile.cl–type, which contains the implementation mapping only in a simple interchange format. Handy for the rest of PA4.
--parent-map
This option causes Cool to stop after type checking and semantic analysis and produce a new file, file.cl–typefile.cl–type, which contains the parent mapping only in a simple interchange format. Handy for the rest of PA4.
--out newnamenewname
Causes Cool to produce newname.clnewname.cl (or .cl–ast.cl–ast, or whatever) instead of file.clfile.cl.

You may encounter other University uses of Cool on the web that mention programs such as coolccoolc and spimspim. Those tool are used for a course on compilers; this is a course on interpreters. We will not use coolccoolc or spimspim. In addition, we use a slightly different version of the Cool language specification, so comparing results against external tools may not be helpful.

Classes

All code in Cool is organized into classes. Each class definition must be contained in a single source file, but multiple classes may be defined in the same file. Class definitions have the form: 

class <type> [ inherits <type> ] {
	<feature_list>
};

The notation [ ... ] denotes an optional construct. All class names are globally visible. Class names begin with an uppercase letter. Classes may not be redefined.

  • Features
  • Inheritance

Features

The body of a class definition consists of a list of feature definitions. A feature is either an attributeattribute or a methodmethod. An attribute of class AA specifies a variable that is part of the state of objects of class AA. A method of class AA is a procedure that may manipulate the variables and objects of class AA.

One of the major themes of modern programming languages is information hidinginformation hiding, which is the idea that certain aspects of a data type's implementation should be abstract and hidden from users of the data type. Cool supports information hiding through a simple mechanism: all attributes have scope local to the class, and all methods have global scope. Thus, the only way to provide access to object state in Cool is through methods.

Feature names must begin with a lowercase letter. No method name may be defined multiple times in a class, and no attribute name may be defined multiple times in a class, but a method and an attribute may have the same name.

A fragment from list.cllist.cl illustrates simple cases of both attributes and methods: 

class Cons inherits List {
	xcar : Int;
	xcdr : List;

	isNil() : Bool { false };

	init(hd : Int, tl : List) : Cons {
		{
			xcar <- hd;
			xcdr <- tl;
			self;
		}
	};
...
};

In this example, the class ConsCons has two attributes xcarxcar and xcdrxcdr and two methods isNilisNil and initinit. Note that the types of attributes, as well as the types of formal parameters and return types of methods, are explicitly declared by the programmer.

Given object cc of class ConsCons and object ll of class ListList, we can set the xcarxcar and xcdrxcdr fields by using the method initinit: 

c.init(1,l)

This notation is object–oriented dispatchobject–oriented dispatch. There may be many definitions of initinit methods in many different classes. The dispatch looks up the class of the object cc to decide which initinit method to invoke. Because the class of cc is ConsCons, the initinit method in the ConsCons class is invoked. Within the invocation, the variables xcarxcar and xcdrxcdr refer to cc's attributes. The special variable selfself refers to the object on which the method was dispatched, which, in the example, is cc itself.

There is a special form new Cnew C that generates a fresh object of class CC. An object can be thought of as a record that has a slot for each of the attributes of the class as well as pointers to the methods of the class. A typical dispatch for the initinit method is: 

(new Cons).init(1,new Nil)

This example creates a new cons cell and initializes the "car" of the cons cell to be 1 and the "cdr" to be new Nilnew Nil.(2) There is no mechanism in Cool for programmers to deallocate objects. Cool has automatic memory managementautomatic memory management; objects that cannot be used by the program are deallocated by a runtime garbage collector.

Attributes are discussed further in Section 5 and methods are discussed further in Section 6.

Inheritance

If a class definition has the form 

class C inherits P { ... };

then class CC inherits the features of PP. In this case P is the parentparent class of CC and CC is a childchild class of PP. The semantics of C inherits PC inherits P is that CC has all of the features defined in PP in addition to its own features. In the case that a parent and child both define the same method name, then the definition given in the child class takes precedence. It is illegal to redefine attribute names. Furthermore, for type safety, it is necessary to place some restrictions on how methods may be redefined (see Section 6).

There is a distinguished class ObjectObject. If a class definition does not specify a parent class, then the class inherits from ObjectObject by default. A class may inherit only from a single class; this is aptly called "single inheritance."(3) The parent-child relation on classes defines a graph. This graph may not contain cycles. For example, if CC inherits from PP, then PP must not inherit from CC. Furthermore, if CC inherits from PP, then PP must have a class definition somewhere in the program. Because Cool has single inheritance, it follows that if both of these restrictions are satisfied, then the inheritance graph forms a tree with ObjectObject as the root.

In addition to ObjectObject, Cool has four other basic classesbasic classes: IntInt, StringString, BoolBool, and IOIO. The basic classes are discussed in Section 8.

Types

In Cool, every class name is also a type. In addition, there is a type SELF_TYPESELF_TYPE that can be used in special circumstances.

A type declarationtype declaration has the form x:Cx:C, where xx is a variable and CC is a type. Every variable must have a type declaration at the point it is introduced, whether that is in a letlet, casecase, or as the formal parameter of a method. The types of all attributes must also be declared.

The basic type rule in Cool is that if a method or variable expects a value of type PP, then any value of type CC may be used instead, provided that PP is an ancestor of CC in the class hierarchy. In other words, if CC inherits from PP, either directly or indirectly, then a CC can be used wherever a PP would suffice.

When an object of class CC may be used in place of an object of class PP, we say that CC conformsconforms to PP or that 𝙲≤𝙿C≤P (think: CC is lower down in the inheritance tree). As discussed above, conformance is defined in terms of the inheritance graph.

Definition 4.1Definition 4.1 (Conformance) Let 𝙰,𝙲,A,C, and 𝙿P be types.

  • 𝙰≤𝙰A≤A for all types AA
  • if CC inherits from PP, then 𝙲≤𝙿C≤P
  • if 𝙰≤𝙲A≤C and 𝙲≤𝙿C≤P then 𝙰≤𝙿A≤P

Because ObjectObject is the root of the class hierarchy, it follows that 𝙰≤𝙾𝚋𝚓𝚎𝚌𝚝A≤Object for all types 𝙰A.

  • SELF_TYPE
  • Type Checking

SELF_TYPE

The type SELF_TYPESELF_TYPE is used to refer to the type of the selfself variable. This is useful in classes that will be inherited by other classes, because it allows the programmer to avoid specifying a fixed final type at the time the class is written. For example, the program 

class Silly {
	copy() : SELF_TYPE { self };
};

class Sally inherits Silly { };

class Main {
	x : Sally <- (new Sally).copy();

	main() : Sally { x };
};

Because SELF_TYPESELF_TYPE is used in the definition of the copycopy method, we know that the result of copycopy is the same as the type of the selfself parameter. Thus, it follows that (newSally).copy()(newSally).copy() has type SallySally, which conforms to the declaration of attribute xx.

Note that the meaning of SELF_TYPESELF_TYPE is not fixed, but depends on the class in which it is used. In general, SELF_TYPESELF_TYPE may refer to the class CC in which it appears, or any class that conforms to CC. When it is useful to make explicit what 𝚂𝙴𝙻𝙵_𝚃𝚈𝙿𝙴SELF_TYPE may refer to, we use the name of the class CC in which SELF_TYPESELF_TYPE appears as an index 𝚂𝙴𝙻𝙵_𝚃𝚈𝙿𝙴𝙲SELF_TYPEC. This subscript notation is not part of Cool syntax--it is used merely to make clear in what class a particular occurrence of SELF_TYPESELF_TYPE appears.

From Definition 4.1, it follows that 𝚂𝙴𝙻𝙵_𝚃𝚈𝙿𝙴𝚇≤𝚂𝙴𝙻𝙵_𝚃𝚈𝙿𝙴𝚇SELF_TYPEX≤SELF_TYPEX. There is also a special conformance rule for SELF_TYPESELF_TYPE:

𝚂𝙴𝙻𝙵_𝚃𝚈𝙿𝙴𝙲≤𝙿  𝚒𝚏  𝙲≤𝙿SELF_TYPEC≤P  if  C≤P

Finally, SELF_TYPESELF_TYPE may be used in the following places: new SELF_TYPEnew SELF_TYPE, as the return type of a method, as the declared type of a letlet variable, or as the declared type of an attribute. No other uses of SELF_TYPESELF_TYPE are permitted.

Type Checking

The Cool type system guarantees at compile time that execution of a program cannot result in runtime type errors. Using the type declarations for identifiers supplied by the programmer, the type checker infers a type for every expression in the program.

It is important to distinguish between the type assigned by the type checker to an expression at compile time, which we shall call the staticstatic type of the expression, and the type(s) to which the expression may evaluate during execution, which we shall call the dynamicdynamic types.

The distinction between static and dynamic types is needed because the type checker cannot, at compile time, have perfect information about what values will be computed at runtime. Thus, in general, the static and dynamic types may be different. What we require, however, is that the type checker's static types be soundsound with respect to the dynamic types.

Definition 4.2Definition 4.2 For any expression 𝚎e, let 𝙳𝚎De be a dynamic type of 𝚎e and let 𝚂𝚎Se be the static type inferred by the type checker. Then the type checker is soundsound if for all expressions 𝚎e it is the case that 𝙳𝚎≤𝚂𝚎De≤Se.

Put another way, we require that the type checker err on the side of overestimating the type of an expression in those cases where perfect accuracy is not possible. Such a type checker will never accept a program that contains type errors. However, the price paid is that the type checker will reject some programs that would actually execute without runtime errors.

Attributes

An attribute definition has the form 

<id> : <type> [ <- <expr> ];

The expression is optional initialization that is executed when a new object is created. The static type of the expression must conform to the declared type of the attribute. If no initialization is supplied, then the default initialization is used (see below).

When a new object of a class is created, all of the inherited and local attributes must be initialized. Inherited attributes are initialized first in inheritance order beginning with the attributes of the greatest ancestor class. Within a given class, attributes are initialized in the order they appear in the source text.

Attributes are local to the class in which they are defined or inherited. Inherited attributes cannot be redefined.

  • Void

Void

All variables in Cool are initialized to contain values of the appropriate type. The special value voidvoid is a member of all types and is used as the default initialization for variables where no initialization is supplied by the user. (voidvoid is used where one would use NULLNULL in C or nullnull in Java; Cool does not have anything equivalent to C's or Java's voidvoid type.) Note that there is no name for voidvoid in Cool; the only way to create a voidvoid value is to declare a variable of some class other than IntInt, StringString, or BoolBool and allow the default initialization to occur, or to store the result of a whilewhile loop.

There is a special form isvoid exprisvoid expr that tests whether a value is voidvoid (see Section 7.11). In addition, voidvoid values may be tested for equality. A voidvoid value may be passed as an argument, assigned to a variable, or otherwise used in any context where any value is legitimate, except that a dispatch to or case on voidvoid generates a runtime error.

Variables of the basic classes IntInt, BoolBool, and StringString are initialized specially; see Section 8.

Methods

A method definition has the form 

<id>(<id> : <type>,...,<id> : <type>): <type> { <expr> };

There may be zero or more formal parameters. The identifiers used in the formal parameter list must be distinct. The type of the method body must conform to the declared return type. When a method is invoked, the formal parameters are bound to the actual arguments and the expression is evaluated; the resulting value is the meaning of the method invocation. A formal parameter hides any definition of an attribute of the same name.

To ensure type safety, there are restrictions on the redefinition of inherited methods. The rule is simple: If a class CC inherits a method ff from an ancestor class PP, then CC may override the inherited definition of ff provided the number of arguments, the types of the formal parameters, and the return type are exactly the same in both definitions.

To see why some restriction is necessary on the redefinition of inherited methods, consider the following example: 

class P {
	f(): Int { 1 };
};

class C inherits P {
	f(): String { "1" };
};

Let pp be an object with dynamic type PP. Then 

p.f() + 1

is a well-formed expression with value 2. However, we cannot substitute a value of type CC for pp, as it would result in adding a string to a number. Thus, if methods can be redefined arbitrarily, then subclasses may not simply extend the behavior of their parents, and much of the usefulness of inheritance, as well as type safety, is lost.

Expressions

Expressions are the largest syntactic category in Cool.

  • Constants
  • Identifiers
  • Assignment
  • Dispatch
  • Conditionals
  • Loops
  • Blocks
  • Let
  • Case
  • New
  • Isvoid
  • Arithmetic and Comparison Operations

Constants

The simplest expressions are constants. The boolean constants are truetrue and falsefalse. Integer constants are unsigned strings of digits such as 00, 123123, and 007007. String constants are sequences of characters enclosed in double quotes, such as “This is a string.”“This is a string.” String constants may be at most 1024 characters long. There are other restrictions on strings; see Section 10.

The constants belong to the basic classes BoolBool, IntInt, and StringString. The value of a constant is an object of the appropriate basic class.

Identifiers

The names of local variables, formal parameters of methods, selfself, and class attributes are all expressions. The identifier selfself may be referenced, but it is an error to assign to selfself or to bind selfself in a letlet, a casecase, or as a formal parameter. It is also illegal to have attributes named selfself.

Local variables and formal parameters have lexical scope. Attributes are visible throughout a class in which they are declared or inherited, although they may be hidden by local declarations within expressions. The binding of an identifier reference is the innermost scope that contains a declaration for that identifier, or to the attribute of the same name if there is no other declaration. The exception to this rule is the identifier selfself, which is implicitly bound in every class.

Assignment

An assignment has the form 

<id> <- <expr>

The static type of the expression must conform to the declared type of the identifier. The value is the value of the expression. The static type of an assignment is the static type of <expr><expr>.

Dispatch

There are three forms of dispatch (i.e. method call) in Cool. The three forms differ only in how the called method is selected. The most commonly used form of dispatch is 

<expr>.<id>(<expr>,...,<expr>)

Consider the dispatch 𝚎𝟶.𝚏(𝚎𝟷,…,𝚎𝚗)e0.f(e1,…,en). To evaluate this expression, the arguments are evaluated in left-to-right order, from 𝚎𝟷e1 to 𝚎𝚗en. Next, 𝚎𝟶e0 is evaluated and its class CC noted (if 𝚎𝟶e0 is voidvoid a runtime error is generated). Finally, the method ff in class CC is invoked, with the value of 𝚎𝟶e0 bound to selfself in the body of ff and the actual arguments bound to the formals as usual. The value of the expression is the value returned by the method invocation.

Type checking a dispatch involves several steps. Assume 𝚎𝟶e0 has static type A. (Recall that this type is not necessarily the same as the type CC above. AA is the type inferred by the type checker; CC is the class of the object computed at runtime, which is potentially any subclass of AA.) Class AA must have a method ff, the dispatch and the definition of ff must have the same number of arguments, and the static type of the iith actual parameter must conform to the declared type of the iith formal parameter.

If ff has return type BB and BB is a class name, then the static type of the dispatch is BB. Otherwise, if ff has return type SELF_TYPESELF_TYPE, then the static type of the dispatch is AA. To see why this is sound, note that the selfself parameter of the method ff conforms to type AA. Therefore, because ff returns SELF_TYPESELF_TYPE, we can infer that the result must also conform to AA. Inferring accurate static types for dispatch expressions is what justifies including SELF_TYPESELF_TYPE in the Cool type system.

The other forms of dispatch are: 

<id>(<expr>,...,<expr>)
<expr>@<type>.id(<expr>,...,<expr>)

The first form is shorthand for self.<id>(<expr>,...,<expr>)self.<id>(<expr>,...,<expr>).

The second form provides a way of accessing methods of parent classes that have been hidden by redefinitions in child classes. Instead of using the class of the leftmost expression to determine the method, the method of the class explicitly specified is used. For example, e@B.f()e@B.f() invokes the method ff in class BB on the object that is the value of ee. For this form of dispatch, the static type to the left of "@" must conform to the type specified to the right of "@".

Conditionals

A conditional has the form 

if <expr> then <expr> else <expr> fi

The semantics of conditionals is standard. The predicate is evaluated first. If the predicate is truetrue, then the thenthen branch is evaluated. If the predicate is falsefalse, then the elseelse branch is evaluated. The value of the conditional is the value of the evaluated branch.

The predicate must have static type BoolBool. The branches may have any static types. To specify the static type of the conditional, we define an operation ⊔⊔ (pronounced "join") on types as follows. Let A,B,DA,B,D be any types other than SELF_TYPESELF_TYPE. The least typeleast type of a set of types means the least element with respect to the conformance relation ≤≤.

𝙰⊔𝙱𝙰⊔𝙰𝙰⊔𝙱𝚂𝙴𝙻𝙵_𝚃𝚈𝙿𝙴𝙳⊔𝙰====𝚝𝚑𝚎 𝚕𝚎𝚊𝚜𝚝 𝚝𝚢𝚙𝚎 𝙲 𝚜𝚞𝚌𝚑 𝚝𝚑𝚊𝚝 𝙰≤𝙲 𝚊𝚗𝚍 𝙱≤𝙲𝙰 𝚝𝚑𝚎𝚕𝚎𝚊𝚜𝚝(𝚒𝚍𝚎𝚖𝚙𝚘𝚝𝚎𝚗𝚝)𝙱⊔𝙰 𝚝𝚑𝚎𝚕𝚎(𝚌𝚘𝚖𝚖𝚞𝚝𝚊𝚝𝚒𝚟𝚎)𝙳⊔𝙰A⊔B=the least type C such that A≤C and B≤CA⊔A=A theleast(idempotent)A⊔B=B⊔A thele(commutative)SELF_TYPED⊔A=D⊔A

Let TT and FF be the static types of the branches of the conditional. Then the static type of the conditional is 𝚃⊔𝙵T⊔F. (think: Walk towards ObjectObject from each of TT and FF until the paths meet.)

Loops

A loop has the form 

while <expr> loop <expr> pool

The predicate is evaluated before each iteration of the loop. If the predicate is falsefalse, the loop terminates and voidvoid is returned. If the predicate is truetrue, the body of the loop is evaluated and the process repeats.

The predicate must have static type BoolBool. The body may have any static type. The static type of a loop expression is ObjectObject.

Blocks

A block has the form 

{ <expr>; ... <expr>; }

The expressions are evaluated in left-to-right order. Every block has at least one expression; the value of a block is the value of the last expression. The expressions of a block may have any static types. The static type of a block is the static type of the last expression.

An occasional source of confusion in Cool is the use of semi-colons (";"). Semi-colons are used as terminators in lists of expressions (e.g., the block syntax above) and not as expression separators. Semi-colons also terminate other Cool constructs, see Section 11 for details.

Let

A let expression has the form 

let <id1> : <type1> [ <- <expr1> ], ..., <idn> : <typen> [ <- <exprn> ] in <expr>

The optional expressions are initializationinitialization; the other expression is the bodybody. A letlet is evaluated as follows. First <expr1><expr1> is evaluated and the result bound to <id1><id1>. Then <expr2><expr2> is evaluated and the result bound to <id2><id2>, and so on, until all of the variables in the letlet are initialized. (If the initialization of <idk><idk> is omitted, the default initialization of type <typek><typek> is used.) Next the body of the letlet is evaluated. The value of the letlet is the value of the body.

The letlet identifiers <id1>,...,<idn><id1>,...,<idn> are visible in the body of the letlet. Furthermore, identifiers <id1>,...,<idk><id1>,...,<idk> are visible in the initialization of <idm><idm> for any m>km>k.

If an identifier is defined multiple times in a letlet, later bindings hide earlier ones. Identifiers introduced by letlet also hide any definitions for the same names in containing scopes. Every letlet expression must introduce at least one identifier.

The type of an initialization expression must conform to the declared type of the identifier. The type of letlet is the type of the body.

The <expr><expr> of a letlet extends as far (encompasses as many tokens) as the grammar allows.

Case

A case expression has the form 

case <expr0> of
	<id1> : <type1> => <expr1>;
	...
	<idn> : <typen> => <exprn>;
esac

Case expressions provide runtime type tests on objects. First, expr0expr0 is evaluated and its dynamic type CC noted (if expr0expr0 evaluates to voidvoid a run-time error is produced). Next, from among the branches the branch with the least type <typek><typek> such that C≤<typek>C≤<typek> is selected. The identifier <idk><idk> is bound to the value of <expr0><expr0> and the expression <exprk><exprk> is evaluated. The result of the casecase is the value of <exprk><exprk>. If no branch can be selected for evaluation, a run-time error is generated. Every casecase expression must have at least one branch.

For each branch, let 𝚃𝚒Ti be the static type of <expri><expri>. The static type of a casecase expression is ⨆𝟷≤𝚒≤𝚗𝚃𝚒⨆1≤i≤nTi. The identifier idid introduced by a branch of a casecase hides any variable or attribute definition for idid visible in the containing scope.

The casecase expression has no special construct for a "default" or "otherwise" branch. The same affect is achieved by including a branch 

x : Object => ...

because every type is ≤≤ to ObjectObject.

The casecase expression provides programmers a way to insert explicit runtime type checks in situations where static types inferred by the type checker are too conservative. A typical situation is that a programmer writes an expression 𝚎e and type checking infers that 𝚎e has static type 𝙿P. However, the programmer may know that, in fact, the dynamic type of 𝚎e is always 𝙲C for some 𝙲≤𝙿C≤P. This information can be captured using a case expression: 

case e of x : C => ...

In the branch the variable 𝚡x is bound to the value of 𝚎e but has the more specific static type 𝙲C.

New

A newnew expression has the form 

new <type>

The value is a fresh object of the appropriate class. If the type is SELF_TYPESELF_TYPE, then the value is a fresh object of the class of selfself in the current scope. The static type is <type><type>.

Isvoid

The expression 

isvoid expr

evaluates to truetrue if exprexpr is voidvoid and evaluates to falsefalse if exprexpr is not voidvoid.

Arithmetic and Comparison Operations

Binary ArithmeticBinary Arithmetic

Cool has four binary arithmetic operations: +, −, ∗, /+, −, ∗, /. The syntax is 

expr1 <op> expr2

To evaluate such an expression first expr1expr1 is evaluated and then expr2expr2. The result of the operation is the result of the expression.

The static types of the two sub-expressions must be IntInt. The static type of the entire arithmetic expression is also IntInt. Cool has only integer division.

Binary RelationsBinary Relations

Cool has three comparison operations: <, <=, =<, <=, =. These comparisons may be applied to subexpressions of any types, subject to the following rules:

  • expr1expr1 is an IntInt if and only if expr2expr2 is an IntInt
  • expr1expr1 is a StringString if and only if expr2expr2 is a StringString
  • expr1expr1 is a BoolBool if and only if expr2expr2 is a BoolBool
  • Otherwise, expr1expr1 may be of any type (including SELF_TYPESELF_TYPE) and expr2expr2 may be of any (possibly different) type (including SELF_TYPESELF_TYPE).

In all cases, the result of the comparison is a BoolBool. See the type checking rules for more information.

In principle, there is nothing wrong with permitting equality tests between, for example, BoolBool and IntInt. However, such a test must always be false and almost certainly indicates some sort of programming error. The Cool type checking rules catch such errors at compile-time instead of waiting until runtime.

On non-basic objects, equality is decided via pointer equality (i.e., whether the memory addresses of the objects are the same). Equality is defined for voidvoid: two voidvoid values are equal and a voidvoid value is never equal to a non-voidvoid value. See the operational semantics rules for more informaiton.

Unary ExpressionsUnary Expressions

Finally, there is one unary arithmetic and one unary logical operator.

  • The expression ∼ <expr>∼ <expr> is the integer complement of <expr><expr>. The subexpression <expr><expr> must have static type IntInt and the entire expression has static type IntInt.
  • The expression not<expr>not<expr> is the boolean complement of <expr><expr>. The subexpression <expr><expr> must have static type BoolBool and the entire expression has static type BoolBool.

Basic Classes

  • Object
  • IO
  • Int
  • String
  • Bool

Object

The ObjectObject class is the root of the inheritance graph. Even the other basic classes (e.g., IOIO and IntInt) inherit from ObjectObject (and thus inherit the three methods listed below). It is an error to redefine ObjectObject. Methods with the following declarations are defined: 

abort() : Object
type_name() : String
copy() : SELF_TYPE

The method abortabort flushes all output and then halts program execution with the error message “abort∖n”“abort∖n”.

The method type_nametype_name returns a string with the name of the (run-time, dynamic) class of the object.

The method copycopy produces a shallowshallow copy of the object.(4)

IO

The IOIO class provides the following methods for performing simple input and output operations: 

out_string(x : String) : SELF_TYPE
out_int(x : Int) : SELF_TYPE
in_string() : String
in_int() : Int

The methods out_stringout_string and out_intout_int print their argument, flush the standard output, and return their selfself parameter.

The interpreter or compiler changes every ∖t∖t to a tab and every ∖n∖n to a newline in the argument xx to out_stringout_string before emitting the resulting string. Note that this is different from normal escape sequence handling, where ∖n∖n would be a single character stored in the string. In Cool, it is two characters, but out_stringout_string prints a newline instead of ∖n∖n.

The method in_stringin_string reads a string from the standard input, up to but not including a newline character or the end of file. The newline character is consumed but is not made part of the returned string. If an error occurs then in_stringin_string returns “”“”, the string of length 0. Note that while literal lexical string constants are limited to size 1024, strings generated by in_stringin_string (or String.concatString.concat, etc.) can be of arbitrary size. There is no special processing of the two-character sequences ∖t∖t or ∖n∖n (or, indeed ∖anything∖anything) during in_stringin_string. Errors include:

  • no input found before end of file
  • string read in contains NUL, the character with ASCII value 0 (in which case the entire string is rejected, even if there are valid characters around the NUL)

The method in_intin_int reads a single possibly-signed integer, which may be preceded by whitespace. Any characters following the integer, up to and including the next newline, are discarded by in_intin_int. If an error occurs then in_intin_int returns 0. Errors include:

  • no input found before end of file
  • malformed input (i.e., first thing after whitespace is not a possibly-signed integer)
  • integer read in is << -2147483648
  • integer read in is >> +2147483647

A class can make use of the methods in the IOIO class by inheriting from IOIO. It is an error to redefine the IOIO class.

Int

The IntInt class provides integers. There are no methods special to IntInt. The default initialization for variables of type IntInt is 0 (not voidvoid). It is an error to inherit from or redefine IntInt.

String

The StringString class provides strings. The following methods are defined: 

length() : Int
concat(s : String) : String
substr(i : Int, l : Int) : String

The method lengthlength returns the length of the selfself parameter. The method concatconcat returns the string formed by concatenating ss after selfself. The method substrsubstr returns the substring of its selfself parameter beginning at position ii with length ll; string positions are numbered beginning at 0. A runtime error is generated if the specified substring is out of range. Substring errors are always reported as taking place on line 0.

The default initialization for variables of type StringString is “”“” (not voidvoid). It is an error to inherit from or redefine StringString.

Bool

The BoolBool class provides truetrue and falsefalse. The default initialization for variables of type BoolBool is falsefalse (not voidvoid). It is an error to inherit from or redefine BoolBool.

Main Class

Every program must have a class MainMain. Furthermore, the MainMain class must have a method mainmain that takes no formal parameters. The mainmain method may be defined in class MainMain or it may be inherited from another class. A program is executed by evaluating (newMain).main()(newMain).main().

The remaining sections of this manual provide a more formal definition of Cool. There are four sections covering lexical structure (Section 10), grammar (Section 11), type rules (Section 12), and operational semantics (Section 13).

Lexical Structure

The lexical units of Cool are integers, type identifiers, object identifiers, special notation, strings, keywords, and white space.

  • Integers, Identifiers, and Special Notation
  • Strings
  • Comments
  • Keywords
  • White Space

Integers, Identifiers, and Special Notation

Integers are non-empty strings of digits 0-9. It is a lexer error if a literal integer constant is too big to be represented as a 32-bit signed integer. 32-bit signed integers range from -2,147,483,648 to +2,147,483,647. Cool integer constants are always non-negative, so valid integer constants range from 0 to 2,147,483,647.

Identifiers are strings (other than keywords) consisting of letters, digits, and the underscore character. Type identifiers begin with a capital letter; object identifiers begin with a lower case letter. Identifiers areare case sensitive.

selfself and SELF_TYPESELF_TYPE are treated specially by Cool but are not treated as keywords. selfself should be reported by the lexer as an identifier and SELF_TYPESELF_TYPE should be reported by the lexer as a type. Both areare case sensitive.

The special syntactic symbols (e.g., parentheses, assignment operator, etc.) are given in Figure 1.

Strings

Strings are enclosed in double quotes “...”“...”. Within a string, a sequence '\c' denotes the two characters '\' and 'c', with the exception of the following: 

\t tab
\n newline

The two-character sequences ∖n∖n and ∖t∖t are called escape sequencesescape sequences. Other escape sequences like ∖r∖r (carriage return) are not part of Cool. These two special escape sequences should not be interpreted or transformed by the lexer; they are handled by the IOIO module and the run-time system.

A newline character may not appear in a string: 

"This is not
OK"

A string may contain embedded double quotes, so long as they are escaped. The following is a valid Cool string: 

"David St. Hubbins said, \"It's such a fine line between stupid, and clever.\""

Note that Cool's interpretation of ∖"∖" may not be what you are expecting. The two-character sequence ∖"∖" (which is not an escape sequence) does not become "" in any sense. Instead, it stays ∖"∖". This is different from most other languages, but simplifies lexing and interpreting. Example: 

class Main inherits IO {
	main() : Object {
		out_string("She said, \"Hello.\"\n")
	} ;
} ;
  • Output: She said, ∖“Hello.∖”She said, ∖“Hello.∖”

A string may not contain EOF; strings cannot cross file boundaries. A string may not contain NUL, the character with ASCII value 0. The lexer must reject source text that contains malformed strings.

A string may contain the two-character sequence ∖0∖0 (backslash zero). However, that sequence does not have any special meaning -- it just yields a backslash followed by a zero inside the string.

The single character with converted integer value zero (the NUL) is not allowed. Any other character may be included in a string.

Comments

There are two forms of comments in Cool. Any characters between two dashes “–”“–” and the next newline (or EOF, if there is no next newline) are treated as comments. Comments may also be written by enclosing text in (∗…∗)(∗…∗). The latter form of comment may be nested but may not contain EOF.

Comments cannot cross file boundaries.

Keywords

The keywords of cool are: classclass, elseelse, falsefalse, fifi, ifif, inin, inheritsinherits, isvoidisvoid, letlet, looploop, poolpool, thenthen, whilewhile, casecase, esacesac, newnew, ofof, notnot, truetrue. Except for the constants truetrue and falsefalse, keywords are case insensitive.

To conform to the rules for other objects, the first letter of truetrue and falsefalse must be lowercase; the trailing letters may be upper or lower case. Thus FALseFALse is not a keyword but a type identifier.

White Space

White space consists of any sequence of the characters: blank (ascii 32), ∖𝚗∖n (newline, ascii 10), ∖𝚏∖f (form feed, ascii 12), ∖𝚛∖r (carriage return, ascii 13), ∖𝚝∖t (tab, ascii 9), ∖𝚟∖v (vertical tab, ascii 11).

Cool Syntax

programclassfeatureformalexprFigure 1::=::=::=|::=::=||||||||||||||||||||||||:[[class;]]+𝚌𝚕𝚊𝚜𝚜 𝚃𝚈𝙿𝙴 [𝚒𝚗𝚑𝚎𝚛𝚒𝚝𝚜 𝚃𝚈𝙿𝙴]{ [[feature;]]∗ }𝙸𝙳( [ formal[[,formal]]∗ ]):𝚃𝚈𝙿𝙴 { expr }𝙸𝙳:𝚃𝚈𝙿𝙴 [ <− expr ]𝙸𝙳:𝚃𝚈𝙿𝙴𝙸𝙳<− exprexpr[@𝚃𝚈𝙿𝙴].𝙸𝙳( [ expr [[,expr]]∗ ] )𝙸𝙳( [ expr [[,expr]]∗ ] )𝚒𝚏 expr 𝚝𝚑𝚎𝚗 expr 𝚎𝚕𝚜𝚎 expr 𝚏𝚒𝚠𝚑𝚒𝚕𝚎 expr 𝚕𝚘𝚘𝚙 expr 𝚙𝚘𝚘𝚕{ [[expr;]]+ }𝚕𝚎𝚝 𝙸𝙳:𝚃𝚈𝙿𝙴 [ <− expr ] [[,𝙸𝙳:𝚃𝚈𝙿𝙴 [ <− expr ]]]∗ 𝚒𝚗 expr𝚌𝚊𝚜𝚎 expr 𝚘𝚏 [[𝙸𝙳:𝚃𝚈𝙿𝙴=> expr;]]+ 𝚎𝚜𝚊𝚌𝚗𝚎𝚠 𝚃𝚈𝙿𝙴𝚒𝚜𝚟𝚘𝚒𝚍 exprexpr + exprexpr − exprexpr ∗ exprexpr / expr∼exprexpr< exprexpr<= exprexpr= expr𝚗𝚘𝚝 expr(expr)𝙸𝙳integerstring𝚝𝚛𝚞𝚎𝚏𝚊𝚕𝚜𝚎Cool syntax.program::=[[class;]]+class::=class TYPE [inherits TYPE]{ [[feature;]]∗ }feature::=ID( [ formal[[,formal]]∗ ]):TYPE { expr }|ID:TYPE [ <− expr ]formal::=ID:TYPEexpr::=ID<− expr|expr[@TYPE].ID( [ expr [[,expr]]∗ ] )|ID( [ expr [[,expr]]∗ ] )|if expr then expr else expr fi|while expr loop expr pool|{ [[expr;]]+ }|let ID:TYPE [ <− expr ] [[,ID:TYPE [ <− expr ]]]∗ in expr|case expr of [[ID:TYPE=> expr;]]+ esac|new TYPE|isvoid expr|expr + expr|expr − expr|expr ∗ expr|expr / expr|∼expr|expr< expr|expr<= expr|expr= expr|not expr|(expr)|ID|integer|string|true|falseFigure 1:Cool syntax.

Figure 1 provides a specification of Cool syntax. The specification is not in pure Backus-Naur Form (BNF); for convenience, we also use some regular expression notation. Specifically, A∗A∗ means zero or more AA's in succession; A+A+ means one or more AA's. Items in square brackets […][…] are optional. Double brackets [[]][[]] are not part of Cool; they are used in the grammar as a meta-symbol to show association of grammar symbols (e.g. a[[bc]]+a[[bc]]+ means aa followed by one or more bcbc pairs).

  • Precedence

Precedence

The precedence of infix binary and prefix unary operations, from highest to lowest, is given by the following table: 

.
@
~
isvoid
* /
+ -
<=  <  =
not
<-

All binary operations are left-associative, with the exception of assignment, which is right-associative, and the three comparison operations, which do not associate.

Type Rules

This section formally defines the type rules of Cool. The type rules define the type of every Cool expression in a given context. The context is the type environmenttype environment, which describes the type of every unbound identifier appearing in an expression. The type environment is described in Section 12.1. Section 12.2 gives the type rules.

  • Type Environments
  • Type Checking Rules

Type Environments

To a first approximation, type checking in Cool can be thought of as a bottom-up algorithm: the type of an expression ee is computed from the (previously computed) types of ee's subexpressions. For example, an integer 11 has type IntInt; there are no subexpressions in this case. As another example, if 𝚎𝚗en has type 𝚇X, then the expression { 𝚎𝟷;…;𝚎𝚗; }{ e1;…;en; } has type 𝚇X.

A complication arises in the case of an expression 𝚟v, where 𝚟v is an object identifier. It is not possible to say what the type of 𝚟v is in a strictly bottom-up algorithm; we need to know the type declared for 𝚟v in the larger expression. Such a declaration must exist for every object identifier in valid Cool programs.

To capture information about the types of identifiers, we use a type environmenttype environment. The environment consists of three parts: a method environment MM, an object environment OO, and the name of the current class in which the expression appears. The method environment and object environment are both functions (also called mappingsmappings). The object environment is a function of the form

O(v)=TO(v)=T

which assigns the type TT to object identifier vv. The method environment is more complex; it is a function of the form

M(C,f)=(T1,…,Tn−1,Tn)M(C,f)=(T1,…,Tn−1,Tn)

where CC is a class name (a type), ff is a method name, and t1,…,tnt1,…,tn are types. The tuple of types is the signaturesignature of the method. The interpretation of signatures is that in class CC the method ff has formal parameters of types (t1,…,tn−1)(t1,…,tn−1)---in that order---and a return type tntn.

Two mappings are required instead of one because object names and method names do not clash---i.e., there may be a method and an object identifier of the same name.

The third component of the type environment is the name of the current class, which is needed for type rules involving SELF_TYPESELF_TYPE.

Every expression ee is type checked in a type environment; the subexpressions of ee may be type checked in the same environment or, if ee introduces a new object identifier, in a modified environment. For example, consider the expression 

let c : Int <- 33 in
 ...

The letlet expression introduces a new variable cc with type IntInt. Let OO be the object component of the type environment for the letlet. Then the body of the letlet is type checked in the object type environment

O[Int/c]O[Int/c]

where the notation O[T/c]O[T/c] is defined as follows:

O[T/c](c)O[T/c](d) = =TO(d)  if d≠cO[T/c](c) = TO[T/c](d)=O(d)  if d≠c

Type Checking Rules

The general form a type checking rule is:

⋮O,M,C⊢e:T⋮O,M,C⊢e:T

The rule should be read: In the type environment for objects OO, methods MM, and containing class CC, the expression ee has type TT. The dots above the horizontal bar stand for other statements about the types of sub-expressions of ee. These other statements are hypotheses of the rule; if the hypotheses are satisfied, then the statement below the bar is true. In the conclusion, the "turnstile" ("⊢⊢") separates context (O,M,CO,M,C) from statement (e:Te:T).

The rule for object identifiers is simply that if the environment assigns an identifier IdId type TT, then IdId has type TT.

O(Id)=TO,M,C⊢Id:T[Var]O(Id)=TO,M,C⊢Id:T[Var]

The rule for assignment to a variable is more complex:

O(Id)=TO,M,C⊢e1:T′T′≤TO,M,C⊢Id←e1:T′[ASSIGN]O(Id)=TO,M,C⊢e1:T′T′≤TO,M,C⊢Id←e1:T′[ASSIGN]

Note that this type rule--as well as others--use the conformance relation ≤≤ (see Section 3.2). The rule says that the assigned expression e1e1 must have a type T′T′ that conforms to the type TT of the identifier IdId in the type environment. The type of the whole expression is T′T′. The type rules for constants are all easy:

O,M,C⊢true:Bool[True]O,M,C⊢true:Bool[True]
O,M,C⊢false:Bool[False]O,M,C⊢false:Bool[False]
i is an integer constantO,M,C⊢i:Int[Int]i is an integer constantO,M,C⊢i:Int[Int]
s is an string constantO,M,C⊢s:String[String]s is an string constantO,M,C⊢s:String[String]

There are two cases for new, one for new SELF_TYPE and one for any other form:

T′={SELF_TYPECTif T=SELF_TYPEotherwiseO,M,C⊢new T:T′[New]T′={SELF_TYPECif T=SELF_TYPETotherwiseO,M,C⊢new T:T′[New]

Dispatch expressions are the most complex to type check.

O,M,C⊢e0:T0O,M,C⊢e1:T1⋮O,M,C⊢en:TnT′0={CT0if T0=SELF_TYPECotherwiseM(T′0,f)=(T′1,…,T′n,T′n+1)Ti≤T′i1≤i≤nTn+1={T0T′n+1if T′n+1=SELF_TYPEotherwiseO,M,C⊢e0.f(e1,…,en):Tn+1[Dispatch]O,M,C⊢e0:T0O,M,C⊢e1:T1⋮O,M,C⊢en:TnT0′={Cif T0=SELF_TYPECT0otherwiseM(T0′,f)=(T1′,…,Tn′,Tn+1′)Ti≤Ti′1≤i≤nTn+1={T0if Tn+1′=SELF_TYPETn+1′otherwiseO,M,C⊢e0.f(e1,…,en):Tn+1[Dispatch]
O,M,C⊢e0:T0O,M,C⊢e1:T1⋮O,M,C⊢en:TnT0≤TM(T,f)=(T′1,…,T′n,T′n+1)Ti≤T′i1≤i≤nTn+1={T0T′n+1if T′n+1=SELF_TYPEotherwiseO,M,C⊢e0@T.f(e1,…,en):Tn+1[Static Dispatch]O,M,C⊢e0:T0O,M,C⊢e1:T1⋮O,M,C⊢en:TnT0≤TM(T,f)=(T1′,…,Tn′,Tn+1′)Ti≤Ti′1≤i≤nTn+1={T0if Tn+1′=SELF_TYPETn+1′otherwiseO,M,C⊢e0@T.f(e1,…,en):Tn+1[Static Dispatch]

To type check a dispatch, each of the subexpressions must first be type checked. The type T0T0 of e0e0 determines which declaration of the method ff is used. The argument types of the dispatch must conform to the declared argument types. Note that the type of the result of the dispatch is either the declared return type or T0T0 in the case that the declared return type is 𝚂𝙴𝙻𝙵_𝚃𝚈𝙿𝙴SELF_TYPE. The only difference in type checking a static dispatch is that the class TT of the method ff is given in the dispatch, and the type T0T0 must conform to TT.

The type checking rules for ifif and {–}{–} expressions are straightforward. See Section 7.5 for the definition of the ⊔⊔ operation.

O,M,C⊢e1:BoolO,M,C⊢e2:T2O,M,C⊢e3:T3O,M,C⊢if e1 then e2 else e3 fi:T2⊔T3[If]O,M,C⊢e1:BoolO,M,C⊢e2:T2O,M,C⊢e3:T3O,M,C⊢if e1 then e2 else e3 fi:T2⊔T3[If]
O,M,C⊢e1:T1O,M,C⊢e2:T2⋮O,M,C⊢en:TnO,M,C⊢{ e1;e2;…en; }:Tn[Sequence]O,M,C⊢e1:T1O,M,C⊢e2:T2⋮O,M,C⊢en:TnO,M,C⊢{ e1;e2;…en; }:Tn[Sequence]

The letlet rule has some interesting aspects.

T′0={𝚂𝙴𝙻𝙵_𝚃𝚈𝙿𝙴𝙲T0if T0=𝚂𝙴𝙻𝙵_𝚃𝚈𝙿𝙴otherwiseO,M,C⊢e1:T1T1≤T′0O[T′0/x],M,C⊢e2:T2O,M,C⊢let x:T0←e1 in e2:T2[Let-Init]T0′={SELF_TYPECif T0=SELF_TYPET0otherwiseO,M,C⊢e1:T1T1≤T0′O[T0′/x],M,C⊢e2:T2O,M,C⊢let x:T0←e1 in e2:T2[Let-Init]

First, the initialization e1e1 is type checked in an environment without a new definition for xx. Thus, the variable xx cannot be used in e1e1 unless it already has a definition in an outer scope. Second, the body e2e2 is type checked in the environment OO extended with the typing x:T′0x:T0′. Third, note that the type of xx may be SELF_TYPESELF_TYPE.

T′0={𝚂𝙴𝙻𝙵_𝚃𝚈𝙿𝙴𝙲T0if T0=𝚂𝙴𝙻𝙵_𝚃𝚈𝙿𝙴otherwiseO[T′0/x],M,C⊢e1:T1O,M,C⊢let x:T0 in e1:T1[Let-No-Init]T0′={SELF_TYPECif T0=SELF_TYPET0otherwiseO[T0′/x],M,C⊢e1:T1O,M,C⊢let x:T0 in e1:T1[Let-No-Init]

The rule for letlet with no initialization simply omits the conformance requirement. We give type rules only for a letlet with a single variable. Typing a multiple letlet

let x1:T1 [←e1], x2:T2 [←e2],…, xn:Tn [←en] in elet x1:T1 [←e1], x2:T2 [←e2],…, xn:Tn [←en] in e

is defined to be the same as typing

let x1:T1 [←e1] in (let x2:T2 [←e2],…, xn:Tn [←en] in e ) let x1:T1 [←e1] in (let x2:T2 [←e2],…, xn:Tn [←en] in e ) 
O,M,C⊢e0:T0O[T1/x1],M,C⊢e1:T′1⋮O[Tn/xn],M,C⊢en:T′nO,M,C⊢case e0 of x1:T1⇒e1;,…xn:Tn⇒en; esac:⊔1≤i≤nT′i[Case]O,M,C⊢e0:T0O[T1/x1],M,C⊢e1:T1′⋮O[Tn/xn],M,C⊢en:Tn′O,M,C⊢case e0 of x1:T1⇒e1;,…xn:Tn⇒en; esac:⊔1≤i≤nTi′[Case]

Each branch of a casecase is type checked in an environment where variable xixi has type TiTi. The type of the entire casecase is the join of the types of its branches. The variables declared on each branch of a casecase must all have distinct types.

O,M,C⊢e1:BoolO,M,C⊢e2:T2O,M,C⊢while e1 loop e2 pool:Object[Loop]O,M,C⊢e1:BoolO,M,C⊢e2:T2O,M,C⊢while e1 loop e2 pool:Object[Loop]

The predicate of a loop must have type BoolBool; the type of the entire loop is always ObjectObject. An isvoidisvoid test has type BoolBool:

O,M,C⊢e1:T1O,M,C⊢isvoid e1:Bool[Isvoid]O,M,C⊢e1:T1O,M,C⊢isvoid e1:Bool[Isvoid]

With the exception of the rule for equality, the type checking rules for the primitive logical and arithmetic operations are easy.

O,M,C⊢e1:BoolO,M,C⊢¬e1:Bool[Not]O,M,C⊢e1:BoolO,M,C⊢¬e1:Bool[Not]
O,M,C⊢e1:IntO,M,C⊢∼e1:Int[Neg]O,M,C⊢e1:IntO,M,C⊢∼e1:Int[Neg]
O,M,C⊢e1:IntO,M,C⊢e2:Intop∈{∗,+,−,/}O,M,C⊢e1 op e2:Int[Arith]O,M,C⊢e1:IntO,M,C⊢e2:Intop∈{∗,+,−,/}O,M,C⊢e1 op e2:Int[Arith]

The wrinkle in the rule for equality is that any types may be freely compared except IntInt, StringString and BoolBool, which may only be compared with objects of the same type. The cases for << and <=<= are similar to the rule for equality.

O,M,C⊢e1:T1O,M,C⊢e2:T2T1∈{Int,String,Bool}∨T2∈{Int,String,Bool}⇒T1=T2O,M,C⊢e1=e2:Bool[Equal]O,M,C⊢e1:T1O,M,C⊢e2:T2T1∈{Int,String,Bool}∨T2∈{Int,String,Bool}⇒T1=T2O,M,C⊢e1=e2:Bool[Equal]

The final cases are type checking rules for attributes and methods. For a class CC, let the object environment OCOC give the types of all attributes of CC (including any inherited attributes). More formally, if xx is an attribute (inherited or not) of CC, and the declaration of xx is x:Tx:T, then

OC(x)={SELF_TYPECTif T=SELF_TYPEotherwiseOC(x)={SELF_TYPECif T=SELF_TYPETotherwise

The method environment MM is global to the entire program and defines for every class CC the signatures of all of the methods of CC (including any inherited methods).

The two rules for type checking attribute defininitions are similar the rules for letlet. The essential difference is that attributes are visible within their initialization expressions. Note that selfself is bound in the initialization.

OC(x)=T0OC[SELF_TYPEC/self],M,C⊢e1:T1T1≤T0OC,M,C⊢x:T0←e1;[Attr-Init]OC(x)=T0OC[SELF_TYPEC/self],M,C⊢e1:T1T1≤T0OC,M,C⊢x:T0←e1;[Attr-Init]
OC(x)=TOC,M,C⊢x:T;[Attr-No-Init]OC(x)=TOC,M,C⊢x:T;[Attr-No-Init]

The rule for typing methods checks the body of the method in an environment where OCOC is extended with bindings for the formal parameters and selfself. The type of the method body must conform to the declared return type.

M(C,f)=(T1,…,Tn,T0)OC[SELF_TYPEC/self][T1/x1]…[Tn/xn],M,C⊢e:T′0T′0≤{SELF_TYPECT0if T0=SELF_TYPEotherwiseOC,M,C⊢f(x1:T1,…,xn:Tn):T0{ e };[Method]M(C,f)=(T1,…,Tn,T0)OC[SELF_TYPEC/self][T1/x1]…[Tn/xn],M,C⊢e:T0′T0′≤{SELF_TYPECif T0=SELF_TYPET0otherwiseOC,M,C⊢f(x1:T1,…,xn:Tn):T0{ e };[Method]

Other Semantic Checks

There are a number of semantic checks applied to Cool programs that are not captured by formal typing rules. For example, a Cool program cannot contain an inheritance cycle. Similarly, a Cool program cannot contain a class that inherits from StringString. These rules are scattered through the Cool Reference ManualCool Reference Manual.

The order in which these other checks are performed is not specifiednot specified. If a Cool program contains both an inheritance cycle and also a class that inherits from StringString, the Cool compiler may report whichever error it prefers.

Operational Semantics

This section contains a mostly formal presentation of the operational semantics for the Cool language. The operational semantics define for every Cool expression what value it should produce in a given context. The context has three components: an environment, a store, and a self object. These components are described in the next section. Section 13.2 defines the syntax used to refer to Cool objects, and Section 13.3 defines the syntax used to refer to class definitions.

Keep in mind that a formal semantics is a specification only--it does not describe an implementation. The purpose of presenting the formal semantics is to make clear all the details of the behavior of Cool expressions. How this behavior is implemented is another matter.

  • Environment and the Store
  • Syntax for Cool Objects
  • Class definitions
  • Operational Rules

Environment and the Store

Before we can present a semantics for Cool we need a number of concepts and a considerable amount of notation. An environmentenvironment is a mapping of variable identifiers to locationslocations. Intuitively, an environment tells us for a given identifier the address of the memory location where that identifier's value is stored. For a given expression, the environment must assign a location to all identifiers to which the expression may refer. For the expression, e.g., a+ba+b, we need an environment that maps aa to some location and bb to some location. We'll use the following syntax to describe environments, which is very similar to the syntax of type assumptions used in Section 12.

E=[a:l1,b:l2]E=[a:l1,b:l2]

This environment maps aa to location l1l1, and bb to location l2l2.

The second component of the context for the evaluation of an expression is the storestore(memory). The store maps locations to values, where values in Cool are just objects. Intuitively, a store tells us what value is stored in a given memory location. For the moment, assume all values are integers. A store is similar to an environment:

S=[l1→55,l2→77]S=[l1→55,l2→77]

This store maps location l1l1 to value 5555 and location l2l2 to value 7777.

Given an environment and a store, the value of an identifier can be found by first looking up the location that the identifier maps to in the environment and then looking up the location in the store.

E(a)=l1S(l1)=55E(a)=l1S(l1)=55

Together, the environment and the store define the execution state at a particular step of the evaluation of a Cool expression. The double indirection from identifiers to locations to values allows us to model variables. Consider what happens if the value 9999 is assigned variable aa in the environment and store defined above. Assigning to a variable means changing the value to which it refers but not its location. To perform the assignment, we look up the location for aa in the environment EE and then change the mapping for the obtained location to the new value, giving a new store S′S′.

E(a)S′==l1S[99/l1]E(a)=l1S′=S[99/l1]

The syntax S[v/l]S[v/l] denotes a new store that is identical to the store SS, except that S′S′ maps location ll to value vv. For all locations l′l′ where l′≠ll′≠l, we still have S′(l′)=S(l′)S′(l′)=S(l′).

The store models the contents of memory of the computer during program execution. Assigning to a variable modifies the store.

There are also situations in which the environment is modified. Consider the following Cool fragment: 

let c : Int <- 33 in
  c

When evaluating this expression, we must introduce the new identifier cc into the environment before evaluating the body of the letlet. If the current environment and state are EE and SS, then we create a new environment E′E′ and a new store S′S′ defined by:

lcE′S′===newloc(S)E[lc/c]S[33/lc]lc=newloc(S)E′=E[lc/c]S′=S[33/lc]

The first step is to allocate a location for the variable cc. The location should be fresh, meaning that the current store does not have a mapping for it. The function newloc()newloc() applied to a store gives us an unused location in that store. We then create a new environment E′E′, which maps cc to lclc but also contains all of the mappings of EE for identifiers other than cc. Note that if cc already has a mapping in EE, the new environment E′E′ hides this old mapping. We must also update the store to map the new location to a value. In this case lclc maps to the value 3333, which is the initial value for cc as defined by the let-expression.

The example in this subsection oversimplifies Cool environments and stores a bit, because simple integers are not Cool values. Even integers are full-fledged objects in Cool.

Syntax for Cool Objects

Every Cool value is an object. Objects contain a list of named attributes, a bit like records in C. In addition, each object belongs to a class. We use the following syntax for values in Cool:

v=X(a1=l1,a2=l2,…,an=ln)v=X(a1=l1,a2=l2,…,an=ln)

Read the syntax as follows: The value vv is a member of class XX containing the attributes a1,…,ana1,…,an whose locations are l1,…,lnl1,…,ln. Note that the attributes have an associated location. Intuitively this means that there is some space in memory reserved for each attribute. The value vv has dynamic type XX.

For base objects of Cool (i.e., 𝙸𝚗𝚝Ints, 𝚂𝚝𝚛𝚒𝚗𝚐Strings, and 𝙱𝚘𝚘𝚕Bools) we use a special case of the above syntax. Base objects have a class name, but their attributes are not like attributes of normal classes, because they cannot be modified. Therefore, we describe base objects using the following syntax:

Int(5)Bool(true)String(4,"𝙲𝚘𝚘𝚕")Int(5)Bool(true)String(4,"Cool")

For 𝙸𝚗𝚝Ints and 𝙱𝚘𝚘𝚕Bools, the meaning is obvious. 𝚂𝚝𝚛𝚒𝚗𝚐Strings contain two parts, the length and the actual sequence of ASCII characters.

Class definitions

In the rules presented in the next section, we need a way to refer to the definitions of attributes and methods for classes. Suppose we have the following Cool class definition: 

class B {
   s : String <- "Hello";
   g (y:String) : Int {
      y.concat(s)
   };
   f (x:Int) : Int {
      x+1
   };
};

class A inherits B {
   a : Int;
   b : B <- new B;
   f(x:Int) : Int {
      x+a
   };
};

Two mappings, called classclass and implementationimplementation, are associated with classclass definitions. The class mapping is used to get the attributes, as well as their types and initializations, of a particular class:

class(a)=(s:String←"𝙷𝚎𝚕𝚕𝚘",a:Int←O,b:B←new B)class(a)=(s:String←"Hello",a:Int←O,b:B←new B)

Note that the information for class AA contains everything that it inherited from class BB, as well as its own definitions. If BB had inherited other attributes, those attributes would also appear in the information for AA. The attributes are listed in the order they are inherited and then in source order: all the attributes from the greatest ancestor are listed first in the order in which they textually appear, then the attributes of the next greatest ancestor, and so on, on down to the attributes defined in the particular class. We rely on this order in describing how new objects are initialized.

The general form of a class mapping is:

class(X)=(a1:T1←e1,…,an:Tn←en)class(X)=(a1:T1←e1,…,an:Tn←en)

Note that every attribute has an initializing expression, even if the Cool program does not specify one for each attribute. The defaultdefault initialization for a variable or attribute is the default of its type. The default of 𝙸𝚗𝚝Int is 𝟶0, the default of StringString is """", the default of BoolBool is falsefalse, and the default of any other type is voidvoid. (5) The default of type TT is written DTDT.

The implementation mapping gives information about the methods of a class. For the above example, implementationimplementation of A is defined as follows:

implementation(A,f)implementation(A,g)==(x,x+a)(y,y.concat(s))implementation(A,f)=(x,x+a)implementation(A,g)=(y,y.concat(s))

In general, for a class XX and a method mm,

implementation(X,m)=(x1,x2,…,xn,ebody)implementation(X,m)=(x1,x2,…,xn,ebody)

specifies that method mm when invoked from class XX, has formal parameters x1,…,xnx1,…,xn, and the body of the method is expression ebodyebody.

Operational Rules

Equipped with environments, stores, objects, and class definitions, we can now attack the operational semantics for Cool. The operational semantics is described by rules similar to the rules used in type checking. The general form of the rules is:

⋮so,S,E⊢e1:v,S′⋮so,S,E⊢e1:v,S′

The rule should be read as: In the context where selfself is the object soso, the store is SS, and the environment is EE, the expression e1e1 evaluates to object vv and the new store is S′S′. The dots above the horizontal bar stand for other statements about the evaluation of sub-expressions of e1e1.

Besides an environment and a store, the evaluation context contains a self object soso. The self object is just the object to which the identifier 𝚜𝚎𝚕𝚏self refers if 𝚜𝚎𝚕𝚏self appears in the expression. We do not place 𝚜𝚎𝚕𝚏self in the environment and store because 𝚜𝚎𝚕𝚏self is not a variable--it cannot be assigned to. Note that the rules specify a new store after the evaluation of an expression. The new store contains all changes to memory resulting as side effects of evaluating expression e1e1.

The rest of this section presents and briefly discusses each of the operational rules. A few cases are not covered; these are discussed at the end of the section.

so,S1,E⊢e1:v1,S2E(Id)=l1S3=S2[v1/l1]so,S1,E⊢Id←e1:v1,S3[Assign]so,S1,E⊢e1:v1,S2E(Id)=l1S3=S2[v1/l1]so,S1,E⊢Id←e1:v1,S3[Assign]

An assignment first evaluates the expression on the right-hand side, yielding a value v1v1. This value is stored in memory at the address for the identifier.

The rules for identifier references, self, and constants are straightforward:

E(Id)=lS(l)=vso,S,E⊢Id:v,S[Var]E(Id)=lS(l)=vso,S,E⊢Id:v,S[Var]
so,S,E⊢self:so,S[Self]so,S,E⊢self:so,S[Self]
so,S,E⊢true:Bool(true),S[True]so,S,E⊢true:Bool(true),S[True]
so,S,E⊢false:Bool(false),S[False]so,S,E⊢false:Bool(false),S[False]
i is an integer constantso,S,E⊢i:Int(i),S[Int]i is an integer constantso,S,E⊢i:Int(i),S[Int]
s is a string constantl=length(s)so,S,E⊢s:String(l,s),S[String]s is a string constantl=length(s)so,S,E⊢s:String(l,s),S[String]
T0={XTif T=SELF_TYPE and so=X(…)otherwiseclass(T0)=(a1:T1←e1,…,an:Tn←en)li=newloc(S1),for i=1…n and each li is distinctv1=T0(a1=l1,…,an=ln)S2=S1[DT1/l1,…,DTn/ln]v1,S2,[a1:l1,…,an:ln]⊢a1←e1;…;an←en;:v2,S3so,S1,E⊢new T:v1,S3[New]T0={Xif T=SELF_TYPE and so=X(…)Totherwiseclass(T0)=(a1:T1←e1,…,an:Tn←en)li=newloc(S1),for i=1…n and each li is distinctv1=T0(a1=l1,…,an=ln)S2=S1[DT1/l1,…,DTn/ln]v1,S2,[a1:l1,…,an:ln]⊢a1←e1;…;an←en;:v2,S3so,S1,E⊢new T:v1,S3[New]

The tricky thing in a newnew expression is to initialize the attributes in the right order. If an attribute does not have an initializer, do notdo not evaluate an assignment expression for it in the final step. Note also that, during initialization, attributes are bound to the default of the appropriate class.

so,S1,E⊢e1:v1,S2so,S2,E⊢e2:v2,S3⋮so,Sn,E⊢en:vn,Sn+1so,Sn+1,E⊢e0:v0,Sn+2v0=X(a1=la1,…,am=lam)implementation(X,f)=(x1,…,xn,en+1)lxi=newloc(Sn+2), for i=1…n and each lxi is distinctSn+3=Sn+2[v1/lx1,…,vn/lxn]v0,Sn+3,[a1:la1,…,am:lam,x1:lx1,…,xn:lxn]⊢en+1:vn+1,Sn+4so,S1,E⊢e0.f(e1,…,en):vn+1,Sn+4[Dispatch]so,S1,E⊢e1:v1,S2so,S2,E⊢e2:v2,S3⋮so,Sn,E⊢en:vn,Sn+1so,Sn+1,E⊢e0:v0,Sn+2v0=X(a1=la1,…,am=lam)implementation(X,f)=(x1,…,xn,en+1)lxi=newloc(Sn+2), for i=1…n and each lxi is distinctSn+3=Sn+2[v1/lx1,…,vn/lxn]v0,Sn+3,[a1:la1,…,am:lam,x1:lx1,…,xn:lxn]⊢en+1:vn+1,Sn+4so,S1,E⊢e0.f(e1,…,en):vn+1,Sn+4[Dispatch]
so,S1,E⊢e1:v1,S2so,S2,E⊢e2:v2,S3⋮so,Sn,E⊢en:vn,Sn+1so,Sn+1,E⊢e0:v0,Sn+2v0=X(a1=la1,…,am=lam)implementation(T,f)=(x1,…,xn,en+1)lxi=newloc(Sn+2), for i=1…n and each lxi is distinctSn+3=Sn+2[v1/lx1,…,vn/lxn]v0,Sn+3,[a1:la1,…,am:lam,x1:lx1,…,xn:lxn]⊢en+1:vn+1,Sn+4so,S1,E⊢e0@T.f(e1,…,en):vn+1,Sn+4[Static Dispatch]so,S1,E⊢e1:v1,S2so,S2,E⊢e2:v2,S3⋮so,Sn,E⊢en:vn,Sn+1so,Sn+1,E⊢e0:v0,Sn+2v0=X(a1=la1,…,am=lam)implementation(T,f)=(x1,…,xn,en+1)lxi=newloc(Sn+2), for i=1…n and each lxi is distinctSn+3=Sn+2[v1/lx1,…,vn/lxn]v0,Sn+3,[a1:la1,…,am:lam,x1:lx1,…,xn:lxn]⊢en+1:vn+1,Sn+4so,S1,E⊢e0@T.f(e1,…,en):vn+1,Sn+4[Static Dispatch]

The two dispatch rules do what one would expect. The arguments are evaluated and saved. Next, the expression on the left-hand side of the “.”“.” is evaluated. In a normal dispatch, the class of this expression is used to determine the method to invoke; otherwise the class is specified in the dispatch itself.

so,S1,E⊢e1:Bool(true),S2so,S2,E⊢e2:v2,S3so,S1,E⊢if e1 then e2 else e3 fi:v2,S3[If-True]so,S1,E⊢e1:Bool(true),S2so,S2,E⊢e2:v2,S3so,S1,E⊢if e1 then e2 else e3 fi:v2,S3[If-True]
so,S1,E⊢e1:Bool(false),S2so,S2,E⊢e3:v3,S3so,S1,E⊢if e1 then e2 else e3 fi:v3,S3[If-False]so,S1,E⊢e1:Bool(false),S2so,S2,E⊢e3:v3,S3so,S1,E⊢if e1 then e2 else e3 fi:v3,S3[If-False]

There are no surprises in the if-then-else rules. Note that value of the predicate is a 𝙱𝚘𝚘𝚕Bool object, not a boolean.

so,S1,E⊢e1:v1,S2so,S2,E⊢e2:v2,S3⋮so,Sn,E⊢en:vn,Sn+1so,S1,E⊢{e1;e2;…;en;}:vn,Sn+1[Sequence]so,S1,E⊢e1:v1,S2so,S2,E⊢e2:v2,S3⋮so,Sn,E⊢en:vn,Sn+1so,S1,E⊢{e1;e2;…;en;}:vn,Sn+1[Sequence]

Blocks are evaluated from the first expression to the last expression, in order. The result is the result of the last expression.

so,S1,E⊢e1:v1,S2l1=newloc(S2)S3=S2[v1/l1]E′=E[l1/Id]so,S3,E′⊢e2:v2,S4so,S1,E⊢let Id:T1←e1 in e2:v2,S4[Let]so,S1,E⊢e1:v1,S2l1=newloc(S2)S3=S2[v1/l1]E′=E[l1/Id]so,S3,E′⊢e2:v2,S4so,S1,E⊢let Id:T1←e1 in e2:v2,S4[Let]

A 𝚕𝚎𝚝let evaluates any initialization code, assigns the result to the variable at a fresh location, and evaluates the body of the 𝚕𝚎𝚝let. (If there is no initialization, the variable is initialized to the default value of T1T1.) We give the operational semantics only for the case of 𝚕𝚎𝚝let with a single variable. The semantics of a multiple 𝚕𝚎𝚝let

let x1:T1←e1,x2:T2←e2,…,xn:Tn←en in elet x1:T1←e1,x2:T2←e2,…,xn:Tn←en in e

is defined to be the same as

let x1:T1←e1 in (let x2:T2←e2,…,xn:Tn←en in e)let x1:T1←e1 in (let x2:T2←e2,…,xn:Tn←en in e)
so,S1,E⊢e0:v0,S2v0=X(…)Ti=closest ancestor of X in {T1,…,Tn}l0=newloc(S2)S3=S2[v0/l0]E′=E[l0/Idi]so,S3,E′⊢ei:v1,S4so,S1,E⊢case e0 of Id1:T1⇒e1;…;Idn:Tn⇒en;esac:v1,S4[Case]so,S1,E⊢e0:v0,S2v0=X(…)Ti=closest ancestor of X in {T1,…,Tn}l0=newloc(S2)S3=S2[v0/l0]E′=E[l0/Idi]so,S3,E′⊢ei:v1,S4so,S1,E⊢case e0 of Id1:T1⇒e1;…;Idn:Tn⇒en;esac:v1,S4[Case]

Note that the 𝚌𝚊𝚜𝚎case rule requires that the class hierarchy be available in some form at runtime, so that the correct branch of the 𝚌𝚊𝚜𝚎case can be selected. This rule is otherwise straightforward.

so,S1,E⊢e1:Bool(true),S2so,S2,E⊢e2:v2,S3so,S3,E⊢while e1 loop e2 pool:void,S4so,S1,E⊢while e1 loop e2 pool:void,S4[Loop-True]so,S1,E⊢e1:Bool(true),S2so,S2,E⊢e2:v2,S3so,S3,E⊢while e1 loop e2 pool:void,S4so,S1,E⊢while e1 loop e2 pool:void,S4[Loop-True]
so,S1,E⊢e1:Bool(false),S2so,S1,E⊢while e1 loop e2 pool:void,S2[Loop-False]so,S1,E⊢e1:Bool(false),S2so,S1,E⊢while e1 loop e2 pool:void,S2[Loop-False]

There are two rules for 𝚠𝚑𝚒𝚕𝚎while: one for the case where the predicate is 𝚝𝚛𝚞𝚎true and one for the case where the predicate is 𝚏𝚊𝚕𝚜𝚎false. Both cases are straightforward. The two rules for 𝚒𝚜𝚟𝚘𝚒𝚍isvoid are also straightforward:

so,S1,E⊢e1:void,S2so,S1,E⊢isvoid e1:Bool(true),S2[IsVoid-True]so,S1,E⊢e1:void,S2so,S1,E⊢isvoid e1:Bool(true),S2[IsVoid-True]
so,S1,E⊢e1:X(…),S2so,S1,E⊢isvoid e1:Bool(false),S2[IsVoid-False]so,S1,E⊢e1:X(…),S2so,S1,E⊢isvoid e1:Bool(false),S2[IsVoid-False]

The remainder of the rules are for the primitive arithmetic and logical operations. These are all easy rules.

so,S1,E⊢e1:Bool(b),S2v1=Bool(¬b)so,S1,E⊢not e1:v1,S2[Not]so,S1,E⊢e1:Bool(b),S2v1=Bool(¬b)so,S1,E⊢not e1:v1,S2[Not]
so,S1,E⊢e1:Int(i1),S2v1=Int(−i1)so,S1,E⊢~e1:v1,S2[Neg]so,S1,E⊢e1:Int(i1),S2v1=Int(−i1)so,S1,E⊢~e1:v1,S2[Neg]
so,S1,E⊢e1:Int(i1),S2so,S2,E⊢e2:Int(i2),S3op∈{∗,+,−,/}v1=Int(i1 op i2)so,S1,E⊢e1 op e2:v1,S3[Arith]so,S1,E⊢e1:Int(i1),S2so,S2,E⊢e2:Int(i2),S3op∈{∗,+,−,/}v1=Int(i1 op i2)so,S1,E⊢e1 op e2:v1,S3[Arith]

Cool 𝙸𝚗𝚝Ints are 32-bit two's complement signed integers; the arithmetic operations are defined accordingly.

The notation and rules given above are not powerful enough to describe how objects are tested for equality, or how runtime exceptions are handled. For these cases we resort to an English description.

In e1=e2e1=e2, first e1e1 is evaluated and then e2e2 is evaluated. The two objects are compared for equality by first comparing their pointers (addresses). If they are the same, the objects are equal. The value 𝚟𝚘𝚒𝚍void is not equal to any object except itself. If the two objects are of type 𝚂𝚝𝚛𝚒𝚗𝚐String, 𝙱𝚘𝚘𝚕Bool, or 𝙸𝚗𝚝Int, their respective contents are compared. << and <=<= are handled similarly. The case for integer arguments is simple:

so,S1,E⊢e1:Int(i1),S2so,S2,E⊢e2:Int(i2),S3op∈{≤,<}v1={Bool(true),Bool(false),if i1 op i2otherwiseso,S1,E⊢e1 op e2:v1,S3[Comp]so,S1,E⊢e1:Int(i1),S2so,S2,E⊢e2:Int(i2),S3op∈{≤,<}v1={Bool(true),if i1 op i2Bool(false),otherwiseso,S1,E⊢e1 op e2:v1,S3[Comp]

... but 𝚂𝚝𝚛𝚒𝚗𝚐String and 𝙱𝚘𝚘𝚕Bool also admit comparisons. String comparisons are performed using the standard ASCII string ordering (e.g., "𝚊𝚋𝚌"<"𝚡𝚢𝚣""abc"<"xyz"). For booleans, 𝚏𝚊𝚕𝚜𝚎false is defined to be less than 𝚝𝚛𝚞𝚎true. Any other comparison (e.g., a comparison among non-void objects of different types) returns 𝚏𝚊𝚕𝚜𝚎false. Note that for some objects this may be unintuitive: if 𝚌c is a 𝙲𝚊𝚝Cat and 𝚍d is a 𝙳𝚘𝚐Dog then 𝚌<𝚍c<d is 𝚏𝚊𝚕𝚜𝚎false but 𝚍<𝚌d<c is also 𝚏𝚊𝚕𝚜𝚎false. Note also that comparison is based on the dynamic type of the object, not on the static type of the object.

In addition, the operational rules do not specify what happens in the event of a runtime error. When a runtime error occurs, output is flushed and execution aborts. The following list specifies all possible runtime errors.

  1. A dispatch (static or dynamic) on 𝚟𝚘𝚒𝚍void.
  2. A case on 𝚟𝚘𝚒𝚍void.
  3. Execution of a case statement without a matching branch.
  4. Division by zero.
  5. Substring out of range. (This error is always reported on line 0, since it occurs inside an "internal" library function.)(This error is always reported on line 0, since it occurs inside an "internal" library function.)
  6. Heap overflow. (You do not need to implement this runtime error.)(You do not need to implement this runtime error.)
  7. Stack overflow.

Each outstanding "method invocation" (static or dynamic) and each outstanding "new" object allocation expression counts as a "Cool Activation Record". (Just to be clear, that second clause about "new" is counting currently-resolving constructor calls, not "total objects living in the heap".) A Cool interpreter mustmust flag a "stack overflow" runtime error if and only if there are 10001000 (one thousand) or more outstanding Cool Activation Records.

Finally, the rules given above do not explain the execution behaviour for dispatches to primitive methods defined in the 𝙾𝚋𝚓𝚎𝚌𝚝Object, 𝙸𝙾IO, or 𝚂𝚝𝚛𝚒𝚗𝚐String classes. Descriptions of these primitive methods are given in Sections 8.3-8.5.

Cool Assembly Language

Cool Assembly Language is a simplified RISC-style assembly language that is reminiscent of MIPS Assembly Language crossed with x86 Assembly Language. It also features typing aspects that may remind one of Java Bytecode.

A Cool Assembly Language programprogram is a list of instructionsinstructions. Each instruction may be preceded by any number of labelslabels. Comments follow the standard Cool conventions. In addition, a semicolon ;; functions like a double dash −−−− in that it marks the rest of that line as a comment. The Cool CPU is a load-store architecture with eight general purpose registers and three special-purpose registers. For simplicity, a machine word can hold either a 32-bit integer value or an entire raw string; regardless, all machine words have size one.

This document assumes that you already have some familiarity with assembly language, registers, and how CPUs operate. We first present a formal grammar and then explain the semantics. Only terms in typewritertypewriter font are part of the formal grammar. Text after ---- is a comment. We use italicsitalics for non-terminals.

register register register register register register register register register register register ::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::= r0 -- general purpose register #0, often used as the accumulator r1 -- general purpose register #1 r2 r3 r4 r5 r6 r7 sp -- stack pointer register fp -- frame pointer register ra -- return address pointerregister ::= r0 -- general purpose register #0, often used as the accumulatorregister ::= r1 -- general purpose register #1register ::= r2register ::= r3register ::= r4register ::= r5register ::= r6register ::= r7register ::= sp -- stack pointer registerregister ::= fp -- frame pointer registerregister ::= ra -- return address pointer
instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction instruction ::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::=::= li register -- load immediate mov register <− register -- register-to-register copy add register <− register register sub register <− register register mul register <− register register div register <− register register jmp label -- unconditional branch bz register label -- branch if equal to zero bnz register label -- branch if not zero beq register register label -- branch if equal blt register register label -- branch if less than ble register register label -- branch if less than or equal to call label -- direct function call call register -- register-indirect function call return -- function return push register -- push a value on the stack pop register -- push a value off the stack ld register <− register [ integer ] -- load a value from memory st register [ integer ] <− register -- store a value into memory la register <− label -- load an address into a register alloc register register -- allocate memory constant integer -- lay out a compile-time constant in memory constant raw_string -- lay out a compile-time constant in memory constant label -- lay out a compile-time constant in memory syscall name -- request a service from the run-time system debug register -- debugging support: print register value trace -- toggle tracinginstruction ::= li register -- load immediateinstruction ::= mov register <− register -- register-to-register copyinstruction ::= add register <− register registerinstruction ::= sub register <− register registerinstruction ::= mul register <− register registerinstruction ::= div register <− register registerinstruction ::= jmp label -- unconditional branchinstruction ::= bz register label -- branch if equal to zeroinstruction ::= bnz register label -- branch if not zeroinstruction ::= beq register register label -- branch if equalinstruction ::= blt register register label -- branch if less thaninstruction ::= ble register register label -- branch if less than or equal toinstruction ::= call label -- direct function
